review: The concept of Chromecast is fantastic, filling in a need that I did not even realize in the past. My friend wanted to project the content from her Android Nexus 7 tablet to the big screen, and Chromecast happened to fit the bill. I wasn't the first mover to buy Chromecast, but I am very grateful that by the time I made the purchase, Google happened to release the screen casting feature (Android only... iOS is not supported, and most likely won't ever be supported).The screen cast feature in Chromecast works almost like a miracast, except with very little to no latency. However, throughout my use with Chromecast I see two major design issues, and these two alone prevent me from giving it a full five stars.First, the Chromecast is not dual-band based, and it does not support 5.0 Ghz band. Thus, unless you have the Chromecast very close to the base station, it is very hard to get Chromecast to work at all (YouTube/Netflix/Screen Casting would fail with almost zero success rate). The current workaround is to buy a long HDMI extension cable that allows me to bring Chromecast closer to the WiFi base station, and at the same time outputs to the big screen in the living room.Second, the Chromecast demands direct Internet access, because every time you perform an action with Chromecast, it "has" to download web app from Google server directly. This requirement applies to even Screen casting, and that alone limits quite a bit of usefulness. For example, you can not bring Chromecast to a business conference, and expect to project your presentation to the big screen via Chromecast without Chromecast connecting to a working WiFi.
